Stocks pecked out modest early gains Thursday as investors took in a raft of earnings reports, housing and unemployment data and a highly anticipated policy announcement from the European Central Bank.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each added 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average checked in with a 0.3% gain. Volume rose 10% on the Nasdaq and was 5% higher on the NYSE compared with trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today received an early lift from the European Central Bank, which upgraded its monetary stimulus efforts to include heftier-than-anticipated asset purchases of nearly $70 billion per month. Purchases of government and European institutional bonds will begin in March and run for 18 months, ECB President Mario Draghi said. The bank also held its primary lending rate unchanged at a record-low 0.05%.

In U.S. economic news, the Federal Housing Finance Agency said its Housing Price Index gained 0.8% in November. That was a step above October's 0.6% gain and stronger than the 0.3% gain projected by economists.

In stocks, earnings reports helped place financial and chip sector plays under early pressure. American Express (AXP) and Discover Financial Services (DFS) dived 4% and 8%, respectively, after delivering quarterly results late Wednesday. SanDisk (SNDK) shed 6% and Xilinx (XLNX) dropped 10%, also following reports made after Wednesday's close.

Southwest Airlines (LUV) leapt 5% after a healthy Q4 report. That bumped the stock to a new high and out of buying range on its first test of 10-week support since clearing a short cup base in November.
EBay (EBAY) climbed 4% after announcing the possible spinoff of its eBay Marketing unit. The gain lifted shares back to their 10-week moving average in the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.

Switzerland-based Logitech International (LOGI) popped 7%. The mouse, keyboard and joystick maker reported a fiscal third-quarter earnings gain vs. forecasts for an 8% loss. The gain drove shares just above a 15.15 buy point in a six-week cup base.

On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) crumbled 11%. The developer of network optimization software reported after Wednesday's close its fiscal first-quarter earnings beat, with revenue meeting analyst consensus projections. But management gave Q2 earnings guidance below expectations and said the company saw "a marked decrease in the number of deals greater than $1 million" during the quarter. The loss drove shares below their 40-week moving average, but stopped short of an October low.

With top-line growth scarce, chipmakers are finding that volume and scale line the path to higher profits. That's creating the perfect space for mergers and acquisitions, says Angelo Zino,…
Stock futures pointed sharply higher, but were off their early highs ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, following some mixed early economic news and as markets rallied in Europe.

Dow futures steered up 118.7 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures traded 25.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.1-point gain. Small caps were positive and steady, with Russell 2000 futures holding a 4-point gain.

The stock market today opens with a two-day rally under its belt, with both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending higher in their trading ranges on Tuesday. Both indexes remain below their 50-day moving averages, although the Nasdaq is positioned for a possible test of that line this week.

Personal spending rose 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, a welcome improvement from October's zero-gain showing and in line with economist expectations. Personal incomes rose 0.3%, a tad below October's 0.4% gain but better than views for a 0.2% advance.

Durable goods orders were flat for the month, sharply below October's (downwardly revised) 2.9% gain, but better than the 0.5% contraction projected by economist consensus. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.
At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.
The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.

Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.

Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.

In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.

Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).

Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.

Micron Technology (MU) tanked 7%, hurt by fiscal Q1 earnings results delivered late Tuesday. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.Micron Technology (MU) tanked 7%, hurt by fiscal Q1 earnings results delivered late Tuesday. The Idaho-based chip maker scored a narrow earnings beat, but revenue missed analyst targets and management guided Q2 revenue and earnings below consensus forecasts.

Leading indexes turned Wednesday's modest opening gains to mixed and busy action, powered primarily by quarterly reports and company news. The Nasdaq backed out of a narrow advance and slipped 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each clung to fractional gains.
Volume swept up 30% on the Nasdaq and rose 5% on the NYSE, gauged against trade at the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today had its little drama sketched out as the Nasdaq rose to test resistance at its 200-day moving average, near the 4800 level.
In stocks,Boeing (BA) and Walt Disney (DIS) led the Dow, up more than 1% apiece. Exotic car maker Ferrari (RACE) throttled up 6% in its first day of trade.

But KLA-Tencor (KLAC) was the stock to catch on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 24% at the open after reporting Q3 results and announcing it would be bought by Lam Research (LRCX) in a cash/stock deal valued at $10.6 billion. Lam's shares shook off premarket declines and soared 7%.

Chip news wasn't all good, however. Micron Technology (MU) dived 7% after a downgrade to underperform from Bank of America. Micron fell 115 Tuesday on word that SanDisk (SNDK) was in late-stage merger talks with Western Digital (WDC), dimming hopes for a chip wedding between SanDisk and Micron.
Biogen (BIIB) gabbed a 6% gain after reporting an across-the-board Q3 win. The stock has been feeling for a bottom in a deep double dip, seven-month consolidation.
Manhattan Associates (MANH) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) bracketed the IBD 50 list.
Manhattan surged 4% on a solid third-quarter report . The jump snatched back Tuesday's loss and sent shares 6% above 65.63 cup-with-handle buy point.
Chipotle slumped 7% after reporting disappointing Q3 results late Tuesday. The heavy-volume loss drove shares below their 200-day moving average.
Water-heating products maker A.O. Smith (AOS) jumped 4% after a mixed earnings report. The light-volume gain lifted shares a bit more than 1% above a 71.91 cup-with-handle buy point.
Cirrus Logic (CRUS) notched a 3% gain. Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Hawaiian Holdings (HA) jumped 2% each.
Overall, losses in the IBD 50 group were relatively mild, the worst being a 1% slip by China-based NetEase (NTES).
Oil prices traded down nearly 2% to $45.45 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories data, due out at 10:30 a.m. ET.

Semiconductor ETFs trimmed early gains to close mildly higher Wednesday as industry mergers made headlines. The major indexes closed near session lows as investors digested a slew of corporate earnings.

Yahoo (YHOO) fell 5% as its 3Q financial results disappointed. Among stocks that brought cheer: EBay (EBAY), whose shares jumped 5% after hours as the e-commerce giant's quarterly profits easily cleared expectations. And chipmaker KLA-Tencor (KLAC), vaulted 19% after a Q3 beat and an announcement that Lam Research (LRCX) would buy the company in a $10.6 billion deal.
Also Wednesday, Western Digital (WDC) announced a $19 billion takeover of SanDisk (SNDK). SanDisk popped 2% on the news.
Despite reversing lower, semiconductors led sector-focused stock ETFs higher on the stock market today. Chip stocks are in comeback mode after getting mauled in the third quarter amid broad losses.
IShares PHLX SOXX Semiconductor (SOXX) finished 0.2% higher after advancing as much as 1.6% intraday. Market Vectors Semiconductor (SMH), which popped 1.4% in mid-day trade, closed 0.3% higher.
Intel (INTC) is the No. 1 stock holding in SOXX. It gained a fraction today but was far outpaced by the surge for KLA.
The ETF holds 30 U.S.-listed semiconductor stocks and caps weightings at 8% to provide broad-based exposure to a concentrated technology subindustry.
SanDisk is the sixth-largest holding in SOXX, at 5% portfolio weighting.
Semiconductor ETFs have rallied over the past three weeks but are trading well below their 52-week highs.
SOXX is 13% off its June high of 101.80. Month to date, SOXX is up 8%. It was gouged 11% in Q3.

The major indexes reversed into losses by the session close, with the Dow giving up 0.3% despite Boeing's (BA) earnings beat, and the S&P 500 giving up 0.6% amid solid results from General Motors (GM).

Carmaker General Motors handily beat estimates as China sales climbed 10%. The stock gapped up as much as 6% Wednesday, closing above its 200-day line for the first time since late June. Boeing rose 2% as it surpassed expectations for both earnings and revenue.
Japan led international ETFs higher Wednesday, while China ETFs slumped as much as 8%.
The largest gold ETF, SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), slipped nearly 1%, giving up its brief hold on the 200-day moving average.
Here's a look at how benchmark exchange-traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.
Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:

S&P 500 companies, sitting on giant hoards of cash, spent $934 million on dividends and share buybacks in 2014 — up 85% from 2005, according to the latest S&P Capital IQ data.
Share buyback ETFs are not nearly as common as dividend exchange traded funds, but are worth a look.
"Companies that do buybacks tend to be more profitable because they're generating free cash flow," says Alex Bryan, a Morningstar analyst.
"Any time management is giving back cash they don't need to investors, that's a good thing."
Strategies that focus on these stocks could boost your investment success in ETFs.
PowerShares Buyback Achievers ETF (PKW) invests in companies that have reduced their shares outstanding by at least 5% in the previous year through share repurchases.
The ETF has produced an average annual return of 17% in the past five years vs. 14% for SPDR S&P 500 (SPY).
PKW holds 206 stocks. Top holding Apple (AAPL) repurchased $10 billion of its shares in the second quarter. Home Depot (HD) and Boeing (BA) are its second- and third-largest holdings.
When companies buy back their own stock on the open market, they effectively make the remaining shares more valuable.
Typically, investors view this "very shareholder-friendly policy" favorably, Bryan said.
Tax-Efficient Move
Plus, it's seen as a more tax-efficient method of distributing cash than traditional dividends.
Investors "can defer tax liabilities as long as they hold on to those shares," Bryan said.

On the other hand, buybacks may be more "lumpy" than dividend payouts, he added. Companies may not repurchase shares, or as many, from one year to the next. That can increase portfolio turnover costs in buyback ETFs.
Besides stock buybacks, other uses of capital can be important barometers of corporate health.
Buybacks are "great from a short-term perspective, but what does it actually do to benefit the company?" says Graham Day, director of product development for Elkhorn Investments.
Elkhorn S&P 500 Capital Expenditures ETF (CAPX) holds 100 stocks in the S&P 500 that have shown the strongest fiscal discipline over the near term.
Capex Efficiency
To measure that, it looks at not just capex spending levels, but capex efficiency. The index method screens for stocks that have maximized sales per unit of capital expenditures.
Day believes the value of capital expenditures has been widely overlooked.
"Capex can be a driving force for a company's future growth," he said. "Adding a campus, investing in new technology — those are the things that help a company to grow from a long-term perspective."
The ETF's top three holdings are KLA-Tencor (KLAC), SanDisk (SNDK) and First Solar (FSLR).
Day expects a rising rate environment to benefit the capex strategy vs. its buyback peer.

"When rates are low, companies want to buy shares at a low price," he said. "When rates are going up, the economy's doing well, and companies are more inclined to take their capital and plow it back into the company."S&P 500 companies, sitting on giant hoards of cash, spent $934 million on dividends and share buybacks in 2014 — up 85% from 2005, according to the latest S&P Capital IQ data.Share buyback ETFs are not nearly as common as dividend exchange traded funds, but are worth a look."Companies that do buybacks tend to be more profitable because they're generating free cash flow," says Alex Bryan, a Morningstar analyst."Any time management is giving back cash they don't need to investors, that's a good thing."Strategies that focus on these stocks could boost your investment success in ETFs.PowerShares Buyback Achievers ETF (PKW) invests in companies that have reduced their shares outstanding by at least 5% in the previous year through share repurchases.The ETF has produced an average annual return of 17% in the past five years vs. 14% for SPDR S&P 500 (SPY).PKW holds 206 stocks. Texas Instruments (TXN) and Analog Devices (ADI) could grapple for Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), which is rumored to be on the sales block amid heavy chip industry M&A action.Maxim stock was up 7% Wednesday afternoon on a report that Texas Instruments was looking to acquire the company. Reports last week had Analog Devices doing the same. Texas Instruments stock was down nearly 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, while Analog Devices stock was up a fraction.Bloomberg reported Wednesday that Texas Instruments is in talks to acquire Maxim. Maxim, which has an $11 billion market value, might not sell unless the company's receives a high premium, sources told Bloomberg.An $11 billion offer would actually be on the low end in terms of big chip industry deals this year. Broadcom (BRCM) is being acquired by Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago (AVGO) for a whopping $37 billion.That deal, announced in May, was the biggest pure-tech merger — until this month's announced $67 billion merger of Dell and EMC (EMC).In June, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR) for $16.7 billion.This month, Lam Research (LRCX) announced it plans to buy KLA-Tencor (KLAC) for $10.6 billion. That same day Western Digital (WDC) said it agreed to acquire SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion.Also this month, Microsemi (MSCC) leaped over the bid by Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) in a battle to acquire PMC-Sierra (PMCS), making a $2.4 billion offer.Chip M&A action has ramped amid an industry downturn with slowing growth, increasing costs and competition, and macroeconomic concerns, particularly in China, analysts say.Maxim makes sense for Analog Devices and Texas Instruments, analysts say, and both figure in on the M&A speculation.Texas Instruments CEO Kevin March, however, seemed doubtful of joining the M&A move, in comments during the company's recent Q2 earnings conference call with analysts."We already have what we believe is a significant scale advantage and we believe we're focused on the two best opportunities that are out there today, being analog and embedded processing," March told analysts. "So those two reasons aren't motivating us to think differently about M&A."MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing suggested in a research report that Texas Instruments might want to change its M&A tune."Assuming robust M&A activity, we think the potential exists for the creation of an analog competitor with comparable scale and cost leadership," he wrote. "Texas Instruments may need to respond pre-emptively and become acquisitive."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter and on Facebook.

Inphi (IPHI) stock gapped up Wednesday on Wall Street after the chipmaker reported Q3 earnings that, for the eighth consecutive quarter, more than doubled year over year.And at least one analyst now sees Inphi as a potential M&A target.For its fiscal Q3 ended Sept. 30, Inphi reported 25 cents earnings per share ex items, up 108% year over year, and above the consensus which modeled 24 cents. Three months ago, Inphi guided to between 22 cents and 26 cents.Although Inphi has more than doubled its EPS in each of the last eight quarters, Q3 was the fourth in a row showing deceleration.Revenue of $62.4 million, up 72%, also beat the consensus of 12 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $61.3 million. Inphi previously guided to $59 million to $63.6 million.In the current quarter, Inphi expects 25 cents to 27 cents EPS on $63.3 million to $65.3 million in sales. Sales would be up 17% at the midpoint while earnings would fall 13% at the midpoint vs. the year-earlier quarter.At least five analysts boosted their price targets on Inphi stock on Wednesday.Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan rates Inphi stock a buy and issued a price target of 31. He was "cautiously optimistic" on Inphi's return to business in China.Inphi CEO Ford Tamer said Tuesday that the chipmaker saw depressed Q2 mobile sales out of China reverse in Q3."We have seen a resumption of the China demand," Tamer told analysts during the Q3 earnings conference call. "We feel confident that Phase II of the China mobile infrastructure has resumed. So, based on the data we have today, we're seeing obviously orders flowing back in."Sundararajan sees "significant chances that Inphi could become a target of acquisition." M&A action within the chip industry hit a fever pitch this year with the multibillion-dollar acquisition deals selling SanDisk (SNDK) to Western Digital (WDC), KLA-Tencor (KLAC) to Lam Research (LRCX), Altera (ALTR) to Intel (INTC) and Broadcom (BCRM) to Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO).Inphi stock carries a high IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a best-possible 99 in its Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group, putting it alongside other top-performing stocks like Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), ARM Holdings (ARMH), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Cavium (CAVM).Cavium stock, set to report its fiscal Q3 after the close Wednesday, was up nearly 1.5% in early trading. Integrated Device Technology stock, which beat forecasts in its Q2 report and announced an acquisition Tuesday, was up more than 3%.In morning trading on the stock market today, Inphi stock was up nearly 8%, trading near 30.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

SanDisk (SNDK) got several downgrades Thursday following news of a megadeal with Western Digital (WDC), while eBay (EBAY) and Boeing (BA) both got new price targets and Visa (V) received new analyst coverage. Meanwhile, SolarWinds (SWI) was downgraded a day after its stock price popped 16% on the news that it's being acquired by investment firms Thoma Bravo and Silver…

The Dow Jones industrial average was in the driver's seat in early afternoon trading Wednesday, while tech stocks lagged, and the S&P 500 was mostly unchanged.The Dow rose 0.4%, helped by strength in United Technologies (UTX), Travelers (TRV), Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) in the stock market today. The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, and the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels.In IPO news, Ferrari (RACE) debuted strongly. Shares priced last night at 52 and opened at 60. The stock was recently trading around 55.81.Meanwhile, two multi-billion dollar deals in the semiconductor industry made headlines.Lam Research (LRCX) jumped 6% on news it's acquiring KLA-Tencor (KLAC) for $10.6 billion. Shares of KLA-Tencor soared 22.5%.And Western Digital (WDC) offered to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion. Shares of Western Digital eased 1%, while SanDisk gained nearly 3%.Market carnage wasn't hard to find despite a quiet showing for the major averages. Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) became the latest target of short-selling firm Citron Research. Shares slumped 30% after being halted earlier in the session.On the earnings front, Chipotle (CMG) retreated 7% after the company reported soft results late Tuesday. Big sellers were in Chipotle in the days leading up to the report.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil lost 95 cents, or 2%, to $45.34 a barrel.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook

SanDisk (SNDK) is not "the pristine, irresistible asset it seemed several quarters ago," according to Summit Research. But at least two analysts see additional bidders possibly attempting to one-up Western Digital (WDC)'s $19 billion offer for the flash memory chipmaker. There's a "50-50 chance" Micron Technology (MU), Seagate Technology (STX), Samsung or SK Hynix could attempt to acquire SanDisk, Summit…
As the PC market slowly stabilizes, No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) has "circled its wagons around the golden goose" — its data center group — Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire said Wednesday.

Sales of chips for data center servers remain a key growth area for Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, though CFO Stacy Smith guided 2015 data center revenue down to low-double-digit growth from the prior outlook of 15% growth, in the company's earnings conference call with analysts late Tuesday.
Intel's Q3 EPS and revenue, however, beat views, and its Q4 revenue outlook was in line. Intel was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 32.
At least three investment banks hiked their price target on Intel stock after the earnings report.
There are signs the PC market is stabilizing, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich told analysts on the call, but he said the recovery wouldn't be immediate, given economic headwinds worldwide.
Intel's Q3 revenue was down a small fraction vs. Q3 2014, helped by higher notebook and desktop pricing, Krzanich said.

"In a time period where PC units are down in high single digits at the TAM (total addressable market) level, we still get enough growth from the data center and the memory business and the Internet of Things to pretty much tread water in terms of revenue growth," he said.
Intel Smartphone Market
For 2016, Intel is focused on expanding its smartphone modem offerings in direct competition with Qualcomm (QCOM), Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan wrote in a research report.
Qualcomm, in conjunction with Mellanox (MLNX) and Xilinx (XLNX), also recently introduced a data center system-on-a-chip that will compete with Intel and others.

In another area, should Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) cut their 2016 capital expenditures, Intel's 10-nanometer chip "stands a good chance of getting the foundry business from Apple (AAPL)," Sundararajan wrote.
Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are providing processor chips for Apple's iPhone 6S and 6S Plus.
The current high end of chip manufacturing is 14 nm, which basically refers to the width of the circuitry etching on silicon. The next evolution will be 10 nm.
Intel, though, is working to ramp its 14 nm production in Ireland, Maire wrote in a research report. Higher expenses and likely poor yield show the process is "still flaky," he wrote.
"If Intel still doesn't have 14 nm nailed and Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are pumping out similar geometries, we may be back to a closer race to 10 nm," he wrote.
Intel Enters 'Attack Mode'
Intel shifted $400 million in capital expenditures to 2016 to reconfigure a chipmaking tool in order to boost output, Krzanich said on Tuesday's call.
Sundararajan and Maire theorized that Intel chip-manufacturing partners ASML Holding (ASML) or KLA-Tencor (KLAC) own the tool. For 2015, Intel cut its capex to $7.3 billion from $7.7 billion.
That capex increase for 2016 "means Intel is in attack mode," Sundararajan wrote.
Sundararajan upgraded Intel stock to buy and boosted his price target to 40. Northland Securities hiked its price target to 39 from 37.50, and RBC raised its target to 34 from 33.
MKM analyst Ian Ing reiterated a buy rating and a 40 price target for Intel stock.

Ing sees Intel's future in the data center market, where its new 3D XPoint chip, which Intel is developing in conjunction with Micron (MU), could provide "significant additional upside not reflected in present growth targets."

Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.As the PC market slowly stabilizes, No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) has "circled its wagons around the golden goose" — its data center group — Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire said Wednesday.Sales of chips for data center servers remain a key growth area for Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, though CFO Stacy Smith guided 2015 data center revenue down to low-double-digit growth from the prior outlook of 15% growth, in the company's earnings conference call with analysts late Tuesday.Intel's Q3 EPS and revenue, however, beat views, and its Q4 revenue outlook was in line. Intel was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 32.At least three investment banks hiked their price target on Intel stock after the earnings report.There are signs the PC market is stabilizing, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich told analysts on the call, but he said the recovery wouldn't be immediate, given economic headwinds worldwide.Intel's Q3 revenue was down a small fraction vs. Q3 2014, helped by higher notebook and desktop pricing, Krzanich said."In a time period where PC units are down in high single digits at the TAM (total addressable market) level, we still get enough growth from the data center and the memory business and the Internet of Things to pretty much tread water in terms of revenue growth," he said.Intel Smartphone MarketFor 2016, Intel is focused on expanding its smartphone modem offerings in direct competition with Qualcomm (QCOM), Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan wrote in a research report.Qualcomm, in conjunction with Mellanox (MLNX) and Xilinx (XLNX), also recently introduced a data center system-on-a-chip that will compete with Intel and others.In another area, should Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) cut their 2016 capital expenditures, Intel's 10-nanometer chip "stands a good chance of getting the foundry business from Apple (AAPL)," Sundararajan wrote.Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are providing processor chips for Apple's iPhone 6S and 6S Plus.The current high end of chip manufacturing is 14 nm, which basically refers to the width of the circuitry etching on silicon. The next evolution will be 10 nm.Intel, though, is working to ramp its 14 nm production in Ireland, Maire wrote in a research report. Higher expenses and likely poor yield show the process is "still flaky," he wrote."If Intel still doesn't have 14 nm nailed and Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are pumping out similar geometries, we may be back to a closer race to 10 nm," he wrote.Intel Enters 'Attack Mode'Intel shifted $400 million in capital expenditures to 2016 to reconfigure a chipmaking tool in order to boost output, Krzanich said on Tuesday's call.Sundararajan and Maire theorized that Intel chip-manufacturing partners ASML Holding (ASML) or KLA-Tencor (KLAC) own the tool. For 2015, Intel cut its capex to $7.3 billion from $7.7 billion.That capex increase for 2016 "means Intel is in attack mode," Sundararajan wrote.Sundararajan upgraded Intel stock to buy and boosted his price target to 40. Northland Securities hiked its price target to 39 from 37.50, and RBC raised its target to 34 from 33.MKM analyst Ian Ing reiterated a buy rating and a 40 price target for Intel stock.Ing sees Intel's future in the data center market, where its new 3D XPoint chip, which Intel is developing in conjunction with Micron (MU), could provide "significant additional upside not reflected in present growth targets."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Stocks finished close to their early lows Friday as trade remained weak heading into the three-day Labor Day holiday. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 1.7%. The S&P 500 booked a 1.5% slip and the Nasdaq shed 1.1%.

August payrolls set the early tone on the stock market today, as job growth undercut expectations by a wide measure. Steel producers and oil drilling contractors posted the session's heaviest losses among industries. Crude oil slipped nearly 2%, but pared some losses after Baker-Hughes' (BHI) weekly land rig count showed oil producers idled 13 rigs during the week, the first cutback in seven weeks.
Some 10% of the Nasdaq 100 were down more than 2%, TripAdvisor (TRIP) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC) posting the biggest declines, down 3% and 2.4%, respectively.

Gains were modest across the S&P 500, with no stock rising so much as 2%. On the downside, energy-related stocks suffered eight of the index's worst losses. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) was also in the top 10, sliding more than 3%.

Among leading stocks, CyberArk Software (CYBR) dropped 5% to lead the declines on the IBD 50 list. The stock has given up an effort to regain its 200-day moving average and is diving closer to the low marked by the Aug. 24 sell-off.

Avolon Holdings (AVOL) and SkyWest (SKYW) were the among the day's biggest winners. Avolon jumped 5% on a $7.6 billion takeover bid from Hong Kong-based Bohai Leasing. SkyWest vaulted nearly 6% on an upgrade to outperform from Cowen.Stocks finished close to their early lows Friday as trade remained weak heading into the three-day Labor Day holiday. Despite an industry report outlining a 2% worldwide quarter-over-quarter decline in Q2 billings, chip stocks gained Tuesday on Wall Street with some outperforming the Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500.
In Q2, Japanese chipmakers showed the biggest acceleration to $1.4 billion in billings, a 40% increase vs. the year-ago quarter.
Taiwan, on the other hand, billed $2.3 billion — the largest chunk of money — but that was a 6% dip from Q2 2014, according to a report by SEMI, a market data research group.
South Korean companies followed with a 16% increase to $2 billion in billings vs. the year-earlier quarter.
Although North American companies landed in the No. 3 slot in terms of dollar bills — $1.6 billion — billings actually declined 33% vs. Q2 2014 when North American companies billed $2.3 billion.
The North American decline was the largest deceleration. European chipmakers posted the smallest Q2 billings at $500 million, a 7% decline vs. the year-ago quarter.
Chinese chipmakers, who've faced a series of recent headwinds including the devalued yuan, posted a small 1% increase vs. Q2 2014, to $1.04 billion in billings.
Overall, worldwide billings reached $9.4 billion, down from $9.6 billion in Q2 2014. Bookings, however, increased 2% in Q2, breaching the $10 billion-mark.

"Ultimately we think that the worst declines in PCs are behind us, albeit the year-over-year trend is still likely down high singles the next few years," Cowen & Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri wrote in a research note Sunday on Taiwan's ODM (original-design manufacturer) semiconductor industry. "After a seasonally weak July, original-design manufacturer PC shipments rebounded in August +20% month-over-month. On this strength all ODMs continued to express confidence that July marked the bottom of calendar-Q3 shipments."
Chip Stocks Rise

Wall Street continued an uptrend for chips Tuesday, carried over from Monday when chip companies bucked a down day. IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor groups (Equipment, Fabless and Manufacturing) closed up fractionally Monday.

On Tuesday, Avago Technologies (AVGO), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Applied Materials (AMAT) and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) were up more than 2%. Qualcomm (QCOM), Broadcom (BRCM) and Analog Devices (ADI) trailed, each up more than 1% in early afternoon trading.
KLA-Tenor (KLAC) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) were up about 1% in the stock market today, whereas Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Qorvo (QRVO) were down around the 1% mark.

In related news, Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan sees a positive near-term for KLA-Tenor. For its fiscal Q1 2016, the company guided orders up, between $450 million and $650 million, with help from Intel, he wrote in a research report. Intel (INTC), up nearly 1.5% Tuesday, accounts for a chunk of KLA's revenues.
Sundararajan expressed concern that KLA had become too financially focused.

"Egged on by the Street, KLAC has evolved into a 'financial' company rather than a high-tech company," he wrote in a report. "However, semiconductor technology has not reached the end of the roadmap and staying at the forefront is important for KLAC, whether they recognize it or not."
Avago, Cavium (CAVM) and Inphi (IPHI) lead their peers in terms of IBD Composite Ratings, respectively 95, 94 and 93 out of a best-possible 99.

Major averages showed modest declines and were mostly in a holding pattern late Monday afternoon in a quiet, low-volume session. The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all fell around 0.5%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking lower than Friday's levels in the stock market today, partly due to the start of Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, at sundown Sunday.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancers on the NYSE by 2-to-1. The ratio was less than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.

This week's highly anticipated two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve on interest-rate policy concludes on Thursday. According to CME Group FedWatch, the market is putting the odds of a rate hike at 25%.

Among the day's movers, Dow component and Nasdaq 100 heavyweight Apple (AAPL) fell off session highs, but still gained 1%, after the company said its new iPhone models are on track to surpass last year's record first-weekend sales of 10 million units. The new iPhone goes on sale Sept. 25.

In related news, industry tracker IDC said wearable device shipments are expected to nearly triple this year to 76.1 million units from 28.9 million in 2014. By 2019, shipments of basic and smart wearables, including Fitbit (FIT) fitness bands and the Apple Watch, could reach 173.4 million units.

Chip stocks also outperformed in the Nasdaq 100. Xilinx (XLNX) picked up 2% after Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to buy from neutral and lifted its price target to 50 from 40. KLA-Tencor (KLAC), Analog Devices (ADI), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) also outperformed.

Inside the IBD 50 , Paycom Software (PAYC) added 0.9%. It's a bit of an anomaly in the market as the stock holds near highs above its 10-week moving average. It's an emerging leader in IBD's Computer Software-Enterprise group

Yahoo (YHOO) slumped nearly 3% after another high-profile executive left the company. Kathy Savitt, who oversaw Yahoo's digital media products, is moving on to Hollywood studio STX Entertainment. The market knocked out healthy early gains Monday, as a broad range of stocks rebounded from last week's slump.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each grabbed 1% gains. The Nasdaq climbed 1.1%. Volume in the stock market today opened mixed. Trade rose 5% on the NYSE, possibly a good sign for the S&P 500 as it rebounded from its 200-day moving average. Volume dipped 13% on the Nasdaq as the index retook its 50-day line.
In stocks,Precision Castparts (PCP) led the S&P 500, soaring 19% on news of its $32 billion acquisition by Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA).

On the Dow, all 30 issues moved higher at the start of trade. Apple (AAPL) and Boeing (BA) led, up nearly 2% each. Chip stocks and drugmakers staked out the high ground among Nasdaq 100 issues. Texas Instruments (TXN) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC) rose 2% each. So did Alexion (ALXN) and Mylan (MYL).
On the IBD 50 list, CyberArk Software (CYBR) and WisdomTree Investments (WETF) swatted out better-than 3% gains.
CyberArk's move lifted shares back above the stock's 50-day moving average as it attempts to begin the right side of a two-month consolidation.
Wisdomtree is climbing off its 10-day moving average, trading 12% past a 22.83 cup-base buy point.

The June-quarter earnings season is slowing, but today's after-hours session is nevertheless a busy one, with big names such as Hertz Global (HTZ) and Kraft Heinz (KHC) reporting, along with smaller names Shake Shack (SHAK) and Vipshop (VIPS), scheduled to report.The market knocked out healthy early gains Monday, as a broad range of stocks rebounded from last week's slump.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each grabbed 1% gains. Intel (INTC) received several upgrades and price target hikes Wednesday, following a mixed Q1 earnings report late Tuesday that showed surging server sales and improvement in the Internet of Things, but sluggish demand for personal computers."We are upgrading Intel to outperform while increasing our price target to 40 from 38, as we believe that bearish PC sentiment is fully priced into shares," RBC Capital Markets analyst Doug Freedman said in a research report Wednesday."Our upgrade is about double-digit data center growth driving a 25% increase in cash flow over the next two years," Freedman wrote. "It is not about quarter-over-quarter changes in inventory and reported gross margins."Q1 revenue at Intel's data center group, which reflects sales of server chips, rose 19% vs. the year-earlier quarter to $3.7 billion. Internet of Things Group revenue rose 11% to $533 million.Analysts at Canaccord Genuity, Nomura, Pacific Crest Securities and Topeka Capital Markets boosted their price targets on Intel stock Wednesday, but Cowen & Co. lowered its price target.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, the No. 1 chipmaker and long the dominant supplier of processor chips for PCs, reported Q1 earnings per share excluding items of 41 cents, up 8%. Revenue was flat at $12.8 billion, in line with Intel's lowered revenue forecast. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS of 41 cents on $12.9 billion in revenue.The chipmaker's Q2 revenue forecast also fell below views. Intel forecast $12.7 billion to $13.7 billion in revenue, with the midpoint below the analyst model for $13.5 billion.Still, Intel stock was up 4.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 33. Intel stock is down 9% this year.Data Center, IoT HighlightedIntel CEO Brian Krzanich said in a conference call with analysts late Tuesday that management is "confident in its strategy to drive growth.""We're focused on innovating in our client business, improving mobile profitability and investing in and growing profitable adjacent markets," Krzanich said. "We are applying our process technology leadership, silicon integration expertise and the efficient use of shared intellectual property. This strategy is delivering results as evidenced by the growth we saw this quarter (Q1) in the Data Center, IoT and Nand (flash memory) segments."Canaccord Genuity analyst Matthew Ramsay, in a research report Wednesday, raised his target price to 39 from 38, noting "continued strong data center, IoT and Nand momentum.""We continue to believe Intel has strong core fundamentals driven by sustained foundry advantages and strong secular momentum supporting 15-plus percent Data Center Group and 20% IoT Group growth potential," Ramsay said. "While mobile losses remain heavy, we believe Intel's modem/system-on-chip technology is gradually closing the gap in a quickly thinning herd of competitors."Krzanich also said "challenging macroeconomic conditions and an appreciating U.S. dollar weighed on our business" in Q1 and that its newly formed Client Computing Group results "reflected weakness in desktop demand and the depletion of PC supply-chain inventories."Krzanich declined to speculate on "rumors" when asked by analysts about acquisition plans, referring to recent news reports that Intel has been in talks to buy programmable chipmaker Altera (ALTR). Altera stock was up 2.5% in afternoon trading Wednesday, near 43.Improving Profit MarginsPacific Crest Securities analyst Michael McConnell in a research report Wednesday boosted Intel's price target to 37 from 35 and maintained an overweight rating, saying Intel's strong data center group results "buoys its gross margin."Intel's closely watched gross profit margin was 60.5% in Q1, down from 65.4% in Q4 but up from 59.6% in the year-earlier quarter. Intel expects its gross profit to improve to 62% in Q2, "plus or minus a couple of percentage points," citing higher selling prices and lower production costs.FBR Capital Markets analyst Christopher Rolland in a research note Wednesday said Intel's full-year revenue guidance (flat vs. last year's $55.87 billion) "was slightly better than feared."He said "the massive reduction in 2015 capital expenditures was a positive highlight as the bears' argument against increasing capital intensity should subside."Intel said it would cut $1.3 billion from 2015 capital expenditures to $8.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million. Yet, shares of chip equipment makers Applied Materials (AMAT), KLA-Tencor (KLAC)and Lam Research (LRCX) were all up at least 1% in afternoon trading Wednesday.Summit Research Partners analyst Srini Sundararajan said in a research note Wednesday that while it may seem "counterintuitive," Intel's lower capital expenditures could actually work in the semiconductor equipment company's favor because "most spending is likely on higher margin, higher revenue-per-unit" products.Intel for the first time in Q1 combined results from its money-losing Mobile and Communications Group with its profitable PC Client Group by forming the new Client Computer Group, which now includes sales from PC microprocessors and chips for smartphones, tablets and other mobile devices. Client Computer Group sales fell 8% to $7.4 billion.Intel forecast full-year revenue as flat with last year's $55.87 billion, which is a touch higher than the current consensus for $55.65 billion. Gross profit is expected to be 61%, plus or minus a couple of percentage points.Cowen and Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri on Wednesday lowered his price target on Intel to 33 from 37 but reiterated a market perform rating."Intel's full-year guidance was not unexpected, but also requires 2015 to be the most second-half loaded year since the 2009 recovery — a factor which raises some eyebrows given ongoing questions around PC demand and mix shift to low-end given the U.S. dollar's strength," Arcuri said.RELATED:SanDisk Q1 Likely To Be In Line With Preannouncement.

Intel (INTC) met lowered first-quarter forecasts for modest earnings growth, thought revenue fell short amid weak PC demand. But with gross profit margins strong, shares rose in after-hours trading Tuesday. The world's largest chipmaker earned 41 cents a share, up 8% vs. a year earlier. Revenue ws $12.78 bil, essentially unchanged vs. a year earlier. Wall Street had expected EPS…

Lam Research (LRCX) beat earnings views and guided forecasts higher late Monday despite Intel (INTC) and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) capital spending cuts as the chip equipment maker benefits from an industry shift to 3D Nand flash memory. Lam Research earned $1.40 a share excluding various items for the fiscal third quarter ended March 29, beating analyst forecasts by a dime.…

Worldwide sales of semiconductor capital equipment rose 18% to $37.5 billion in 2014, but not all regions and companies benefited from the robust increase. Taiwan remained the largest market for new chip gear for the third year in a row, with $9.41 billion in sales, or 25% of the total market, according to trade group SEMI. But its sales dipped…

Intel late Tuesday reported mixed Q1 earnings as sluggish demand for personal computers offset robust sales of server chips and for the Internet of Things. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, the No. 1 supplier of processor chips for PCs, reported earnings per share excluding items of 41 cents, up 8% from the year-earlier quarter. Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.

Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today

Tata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.

Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.

Stocks opened battling near break-even points Friday, unsettled by mixed earnings reports and wavering oil prices.
The Nasdaq held out a 0.2% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.2%.
Trade was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE compared with volume at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today borrowed premarket strength from Europe's advancing stocks and from an upward blip in oil prices. But oil fell back into mild losses, and a spray of blue chip earnings reports helped put a dent in early trade.
Economic news was also lukewarm. A preliminary U.S. manufacturing index from researcher Markit showed no change in January, at 53.7. That disappointed expectations for an uptick to 54.

Existing-home sales data were mixed, rising to an annualized rate of 5.04 million for December, according to the National Association of Realtors. That beat November's 4.92 sales pace, but stopped just short of economist projections for 5.05 million.
The Conference Board reported its Leading Economic Indicators Index eased to 0.5%, down from 0.6% in November. Analyst had estimated a dip to 0.4%.
In stocks, McDonald's (MCD) and General Electric (GE) edged higher, Kimberly Clark (KMB) and Rockwell Collins (COL) fell after reporting quarterly results.
Starbucks (SBUX) was a big early winner, up 6% to new highs after a strong Q4 report. The strong volume gain also broke the stock out past buy points at 83.43 and 84.30.
The IBD 50 list opened mixed, half up, half down.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2% to top the list. The move sent shares past a 134.60 buy point in a seven-week flat base.
Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 2%, the widest loss on the list. The stock remains extended, trading below a Jan. 13 high and its 10-week line of support.

United Parcel Service (UPS) collapsed 10%. The freight heavyweight offered preliminary fourth-quarter earnings guidance far below consensus views. The gap-down loss pulled shares away from a new high, sending the stock through its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

Chip sector stocks were taking some hard hits, led by KLA-Tencor (KLAC), which fell 7%. The chip equipment maker reported stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings. But management guided Q3 revenue and earnings well below consensus. The loss drove shares back below the stock's 10-week moving average in heavy trade.Stocks opened battling near break-even points Friday, unsettled by mixed earnings reports and wavering oil prices.The Nasdaq held out a 0.2% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.2%.Trade was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE compared with volume at the same time Thursday.The stock market today borrowed premarket strength from Europe's advancing stocks and from an upward blip in oil prices. But oil fell back into mild losses, and a spray of blue chip earnings reports helped put a dent in early trade.Economic news was also lukewarm. A preliminary U.S. manufacturing index from researcher Markit showed no change in January, at 53.7. That disappointed expectations for an uptick to 54.Existing-home sales data were mixed, rising to an annualized rate of 5.04 million for December, according to the National Association of Realtors. That beat November's 4.92 sales pace, but stopped just short of economist projections for 5.05 million.The Conference Board reported its Leading Economic Indicators Index eased to 0.5%, down from 0.6% in November. Analyst had estimated a dip to 0.4%.In stocks, McDonald's (MCD) and General Electric (GE) edged higher, Kimberly Clark (KMB) and Rockwell Collins (COL) fell after reporting quarterly results.Starbucks (SBUX) was a big early winner, up 6% to new highs after a strong Q4 report. The strong volume gain also broke the stock out past buy points at 83.43 and 84.30.The IBD 50 list opened mixed, half up, half down.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2% to top the list. The move sent shares past a 134.60 buy point in a seven-week flat base.Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 2%, the widest loss on the list. The stock remains extended, trading below a Jan. 13 high and its 10-week line of support.United Parcel Service (UPS) collapsed 10%. The freight heavyweight offered preliminary fourth-quarter earnings guidance far below consensus views. The gap-down loss pulled shares away from a new high, sending the stock through its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.Chip sector stocks were taking some hard hits, led by KLA-Tencor (KLAC), which fell 7%. The chip equipment maker reported stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings. But management guided Q3 revenue and earnings well below consensus. The loss drove shares back below the stock's 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

A proposed merger between Cypress Semiconductor and Spansion prompted analysts' upgrades and price target increases on Tuesday, and shares of both companies surged. Cypress Semiconductor (CY) stock was up 16% near 12 in midday trading on the stock market today. Spansion (CODE) was up 23% near 28. Cypress will acquire Spansion for about $1.6 billion to form a company specializing…
Chip stocks fueled a day of outperformance for the Nasdaq Monday.

The composite was up 0.8% in afternoon trading, buoyed by strength in Nasdaq 100 chip names like KLA-Tencor (KLAC), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), SanDisk (SNDK) and Intel (INTC). The S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average picked up less than 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking well below Friday's levels, but volume was heavy Friday due to options expiration.
In the stock market today, biotechs also did well, with top-rated names like Celgene (CELG), Medivation (MDVN) and Enanta (ENTA) leading the charge. All three scored gains of at least 2%.

In the retail sector, Five Below (FIVE) extended gains. It reports earnings Dec. 4. Shares rose 0.5%. It's still deep inside a lengthy consolidation, but it recently cleared an alternative entry of 43.83. With a five-year annualized earnings growth rate of 61% and sales growth rate of 45%, Five Below is no stranger to fast growth.

Elsewhere, drugmaker Lannett (LCI) reclaimed a prior buy point of 46.84 in heavy volume, rising 6%. The retaking of the buy point coincided with support at the 50-day moving average. Lannett is trading 3.5% above the buy point. Lannett had been under pressure for most of November despite reporting another quarter of triple-digit earnings and sales growth on Nov. 3.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) outperformed, rising 3% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Expectations are high for a solid quarter from the provider of network security infrastructure products. The Thomson Reuters consensus estimate is for profit of 12 cents a share, up 50% from a year ago. Sales are seen rising 42% to $181.7 million.
Oil and gas-related groups were pressured again. Five of the day's worst-10 performers hailed from the sector.

Results are also due after the close from China-based Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) and Workday (WDAY). Workday isn't profitable yet but has shown strong sales growth in recent quarters. It's working on a cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 97.50. Shares lost 0.9%.

The economic calendar is light this week due to the Thanksgiving holiday. On Tuesday, watch for the second estimate to Q3 gross domestic product. Stock futures showed moderate losses ahead of Monday's open.
Dow futures were 40.4 points below fair market value and dropping. Nasdaq 100 futures were off a mild 5.6 points. S&P 500 futures slipped 5.4 points.
The stock market today opens the week on a fairly tame note with regard to quarterly earnings reports.
Drug giant Merck (MRK) was down a fraction after delivering third-quarter results.

Allergan (AGN) climbed 2% after clearing analyst earnings and revenue forecasts for the third quarter, and guiding fourth-quarter earnings above consensus projections. The stock might also have received a boost from news reports saying Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) was prepared to raise its takeover offer to nearly $200 per share, from its prior offer of around $179.
Allergan shares ended Friday extended above a 174.05 buy point, after a quick pullback to test support at the 10-week moving average.

Chip equipment maker KLA-Tencor (KLAC) popped 5% in premarket trade. The stock gained 11% last week, after announcing on Thursday it would borrow $2.5 billion to finance a special dividend of $16.50 per share.

Brazil-based stocks were selling off hard ahead of the open after a final presidential vote Sunday re-elected incumbent president Dilma Rousseff. State-owned oil producer Petrobras (PBR) tumbled 16%. Banks Itau Unibanco (ITUB) and Banco Bradesco (BBD) were down 11% each. Telecom TIM Participacoes (TSU) dropped 8% and miner ValeVALE fell 5%.

Elsewhere overseas, China's markets closed with narrow losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 bumped up 0.6%. In Europe, news of 25 banks failing the European Central Bank's stress test exercise over the weekend helped place European stocks under mild selling pressure near midday. But the failure's did not broadly surprise analysts and did not trigger any new capitalization requirements.
The dollar was up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Commodities were down, with oil hammered back down to just above $80 a barrel.

A raft of heavyweight U.S. and global news did little to inspire investors Friday, as stock futures traded in narrowly mixed terrain ahead of the open.
Dow futures traded 3.6 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures clung to a fractional gain. Nasdaq 100 futures dipped 2.8%.
In one of the stock market today's closely watched pieces of news, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said it would keep its production target unchanged at 30 million barrels per day.

It was basically a no-surprise decision, although there was some speculation that the group could increase the target, as a number of countries are already producing above their quotas. Oil prices shifted from mild losses prior to the announcement to gains of half-percent.

Greece on Thursday postponed its $334 million debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund, opting instead to roll all its payments due into one, $1.8 billion lump sum now due at the end of June.

The move gives time for further negotiations as Greece attempts to gain access to the $8.06 billion in bailout funds being held up by eurozone creditors and pending changes in the Greek economy. It also severely increases the risk of default if no agreement on bailout funding is reached.

The big news on the U.S. economy was generally positive, with the Labor Department reporting nonfarm payrolls added 280,000 jobs in May. That was up from a downwardly revised 221,000 in April and above estimates for a decline to 220,000. Private payrolls added the bulk of the new hires, 262,000, better than estimates for 215,000.
The workforce participation rate ticked up. The unemployment rate rose to 5.5% from 5.4%. Growth in average hourly earnings rose to 0.3% vs. 0.1% in April and beat forecasts for 0.2%.
The Federal Reserve is on deck, set to release April consumer credit data at 3 p.m. ET.

In stocks, Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) rattled off a 3% gain after reporting first-quarter sales and earnings above analyst consensus expectations. The stock has been in a flattish consolidation below an October high. It ended Thursday 125% above its April 2014 IPO price.

Apparel maker Vince Holding (VNCE) tumbled 11% before the open. The New York-based firm reported narrow Q1 sales and earnings beats, but management lowered its full-year guidance to below consensus views. The stock has been in a steep decline since December.
Apparel retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) dived 13% in premarket action. Trading was halted on the stock in after-hours action Thursday following a weak Q1 report.

Overseas, another volatile session in China's mainland markets saw the Shanghai Composite again reversing from steep losses, posting a 1.5% gain Friday and ending the week 8% higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slipped 1.1% Friday to finish the week flat. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 inched lower Friday, also ending the week with little change.

In Europe, markets were under pressure, with the CAC-40 in Paris down 1.5% and Frankfurt's DAX down 1.4% as investors reacted to the Greece/IMF news. The Paris and Frankfurt indexes were trading down a bit less than 2% for the week. London's FTSE 100 was tracking toward a 2.7% weekly decline.

On other markets, bonds eased. Major averages ended the week with a clunker Friday as Wall Street weighed more corporate earnings and continued unrest in Ukraine. The news wasn't good on either front. The Nasdaq underperformed, falling 1.8%. It met resistance at the 10-week moving average last week as it reversed lower to finish the week with a small loss. Lukewarm earnings from Amazon.com (AMZN)…

Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. The latest report from the chip-equipment manufacturing industry is a positive for industry leaders such as Applied Materials (AMAT). U.S. manufacturers of chip equipment booked $1.47 billion in new orders in June, while they billed $1.34 billion for products sold. That's a book-to-bill ratio of 1.09, which means $109 in orders came in for every $100 billed, indicating strong demand,…
Stocks wobbled in and out of narrow gains early Friday.

The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrials nibbled at 0.1% gains, but were tipping in and out of mixed trade. Nasdaq volume rose 38%. Trade on the NYSE was 13% below levels at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today wraps up the season's first weak of heavy-duty reporting. Ford (F) slumped 3%, Procter & Gamble (PG) gained 3% after reporting Q3 results. Microsoft (MSFT), United Parcel Service (UPS) and Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) were all moving in heavy trade.

Amazon.com (AMZN) dropped 7% to stake out the low end of the Nasdaq 100 list. The company reported a wide third-quarter earnings miss, with revenue and Q4 guidance also disappointing analysts. Shares have pulled back almost to their lows in May.

Chip sector stocks were mixed. Test equipment maker KLA-Tencor (KLAC) hammered out a 10% gain after reporting mixed fiscal first-quarter results, while launching a restructuring plan that includes a 23% dividend.

Programmable chip pioneer Alterra (ALTR) slumped 4%, despite reporting Q3 earnings and revenue above consensus forecasts. The midpoint of management's Q4 revenue guidance was below consensus estimates.
Leaders posted a positive open, with three in five IBD 50 stocks advancing out of the starting gate.
Drugmakers Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) and Gilead Sciences (GILD) took an early lead, up 3% each. Jazz is climbing the right side of a second-stage cup base. It is 6% below the 176.46 buy point.
Gilead is just below a 110.69 buy point in a second-stage base.
Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) also edged up to a 3% gain. The advance put the cloud and smartphone service provider almost 3% above a 45.69 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Friday morning's economic news took a back seat to earnings reports. The Commerce Department reported that new home sales slumped to an annualized rate of 467,000 in September. That was weaker than the initial 504,000 rate estimated for August, but just above that month's revised 466,000 number. KLA-Tencor (KLAC) stock, which this month hit 14-year highs, fell as much as 4% Friday after the chip-equipment maker's shares fiscal Q4 earnings late Thursday missed Wall Street and its own expectations. KLA-Tencor stock, though, recovered somewhat and was down nearly 2%, near 72, in afternoon trading in the stock market today. The Milpitas, Calif.-based company reported earnings per share…

No. 1 chip gear maker Applied Materials, saying it's negotiating the biggest changes in the history of its industry, late Thursday posted a 56% jump in EPS, beating analyst expectations.Revenue rose 14.7% and slightly missed Wall Street expectations, but Applied (AMAT) stock was up nearly 2% in after-hours trading, after it released results for its fiscal Q3 ended July 27.The company's Q4 earnings outlook slightly beat views, while its revenue outlook was just light, as the company continues the process of acquiring one of its top rivals, Tokyo Electron, pending regulator approval.Despite the industry "being in the middle of the biggest changes in its history enabled by materials innovation," Applied's operating profit margin has improved for seven quarters in a row, company CEO Gary Dickerson said in a conference call with analysts."More than any other supplier, Applied Materials is a 'transistor performance' company, and thus in a sweet spot to capture more of the spending mix as customers adopt new transistor architectures in an effort to ward off a slowdown in Moore's Law," said Cowen & Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri in a research report Thursday.Moore's Law refers to Intel (INTC) Gordon Moore's famous observation that the number of "components per integrated function" on a silicon chip — that is, computing power — will double roughly every 18 months.For Q3, Applied reported earnings per share minus items of 28 cents, up from 18 cents in the year-earlier quarter and a penny above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue of $2.27 billion fell just shy of the $2.3 billion analyst consensus.Applied said Q3 orders rose 24% to $2.48 billion.Projects Double-Digit EPS RiseThe Santa Clara, Calif.-based company expects EPS ex items in the current quarter of 25 cents to 29 cents, up 32% to 53%, on revenue of $2.19 billion to $2.33 billion, up 10% to 17%. Analysts has been modeling 26 cents and $2.28 billion.Applied Materials' growth continues as it awaits its merger with Tokyo Electron, which still needs the blessing of U.S. regulators and China's Ministry of Commerce.The merged company will take the name Eteris, which company executives say is derived from the concept of "eternal innovation for society."The merger would create a company with a market value estimated at $29 billion in September 2013, when Applied and Tokyo Electron announced their marriage. Applied executives said Thursday that they still expect the deal to close this year.Like other chip equipment makers, Applied Materials experiences cyclical earnings results as its customers — makers of chips, displays and solar panels — react to demand by building up or cutting back their production capacity.But Applied Materials and its peers could benefit from a positive outlook, as worldwide semiconductor capital equipment spending is projected to total $37.5 billion in 2014, up 12.2% from 2013, market tracker Gartner says.Global semiconductor capital equipment spending fell 11.6% to $33.4 billion in 2013. Gartner also forecasts a 12.8% increase in 2015, to $42.3 billion, before seeing a 5.9% decline in 2016, to $39.8 billion.The capital spending forecast estimates total capital spending from all forms of semiconductor manufacturers, including foundries, back-end assembly and test services companies.Applied Materials said orders for its Silicon Systems Group — or sales of equipment to chipmakers — fell 6% last quarter to $1.57 billion, led by declines in purchases of tools for foundry chipmakers and DRAM memory chip manufacturing.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mahesh Sanganeria wrote in a research report that Applied Materials' rivals such as KLA-Tencor (KLAC) also are likely feeling the impact from a delay in foundry spending.Milpitas, Calif.-based KLA-Tencor in late July reported EPS minus items for it fiscal Q4 ended June 30 of 80 cents, down 2% from the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had expected 86 cents. Revenue rose 2% to $734 million, just above the consensus of $733.7 million.

Stocks were sharply lower midday Friday amid a flurry of earnings reports and continued tensions in Ukraine.

The Nasdaq slumped 1.4% as Internet retailers, software-makers and chipmakers led the sell-off. The Dow was off 0.8% and the S&P 500 0.7%. Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges in the stock market today.

Amazon (AMZN) fell 9% in huge turnover after its Q1 profit, reported late Thursday, met views and revenue beat slightly. The stock, which has been trading below its 50-day and 200-day lines since April 3, has now given up all of a 30% gain from its prior breakout. The online retailer expects an operating loss in Q2 and its revenue outlook disappointed.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) gapped down and plunged 30% to its lowest level since August 2012. Before the open, the database software-maker announced fiscal Q3 earnings that topped forecasts by a nickel, but sales missed views.
Freescale Semiconductor (FSL) sank 11% in heavy turnover, slicing its 50-day line for the first time since late January. The chipmaker late Thursday reported Q1 results above estimates.

KLA-Tencor (KLAC) dropped 7% in busy trade after its fiscal Q3 results topped views after-hours, but it guided Q4 below consensus forecasts. B. Riley on Friday cut the chipmaker to neutral from buy and lowered its price target.

On the upside, Weatherford International (WFT) gapped up and surged 11% to a multiyear high in brisk trade. The stock is 17% above a 17.48 cup-base buy point that it cleared last month. The oil and gas drilling gear-maker late Thursday beat Q1 EPS views by 2 cents, though revenue missed. It guided full-year profit above forecasts.
